title: 107_hr1621
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001" and includes findings and purposes. The Arabia Mountain area in Georgia contains diverse natural, cultural, and historical resources that deserve recognition and conservation. Partnerships between public and private entities are seen as the best way to manage these resources. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve protects various ecosystems and federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park is a rare granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve shows evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain display the history of granite mining. Klondike may become a National Historic District. Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and interpret these sites. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, promote, and interpret natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites. It also aims to assist Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing and implementing a program to protect, enhance, and interpret the significant resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA establishes the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area. SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA is established in the State, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The map of the area is available for public inspection. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance will manage the heritage area. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter into contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers the interests of various groups within the area. Priorities will be given to certain aspects of the management plan. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area has priorities in implementing actions from the management plan, including assisting government and nonprofit organizations, encouraging land use policies, conducting quarterly public meetings, and submitting an annual report to the Secretary. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to provide all records for audit relating to the expenditure of Federal funds and ensure receiving organizations do the same. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real estate. Federal funds under this Act can be used to acquire real property or an interest in real property. The management entity can also use other Federal funds for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area that protects and enhances its natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources. The plan should be based on the preferred concept from the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study" and consider State and local plans, involving residents, public agencies, and private organizations. It must include an inventory of resources in the area. The management plan for the heritage area includes a list of significant properties to be preserved, an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and enjoyment of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation involving various entities. The management plan for the heritage area must include identification of funding sources, evaluation of the management entity, and submission to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding under the Act. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan for the heritage area within 90 days of receiving it. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons and recommendations for revisions to the management entity. After the Secretary approves the management plan for the heritage area, the management entity can periodically review and submit recommendations for revisions to the plan. The Secretary must approve or disapprove any revisions within 90 days of submission. The management entity can review and propose revisions to the approved plan for the heritage area, but no funds can be used to implement any proposed revisions until approved by the Secretary. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share capped at 50%. Secretary's grant authority ends on September 30, 2016.
